We also want to better understand how FRONTLINE's documentaries impact the ways in which you see the world and one another. So to achieve this goal, we invite you to engage in a new kind of conversation. This type of conversation is centered on sharing personal stories from our own lives and experiences, rather than beginning the conversation with our positions on the issues. 37.words: Artificial intelligence is one of those key pieces that has made it possible now to do driverless vehicles where it wasn't possible 10 years ago, particularly in the ability to see and understand scenes. A lot of people don't know this, but it's remarkably hard for computers until very, very recently, to do even the most basic visual tasks, like seeing a picture of a person and knowing that it's a person. And we've made gigantic strides with artificial intelligence and being able to see and understanding tasks. And that's obviously fundamental to being able to understand the world around you, with the sensors that you have available. I think that you'll see the first vehicles operating with no one inside the moving freight in the next few years. And then you're going to see that expanding to more freight, more geographies, more weather over time, as that capability builds up. We're talking less than half a decade.

39.words: This is one of the most remarkable stories in US labor history I think, is the decline of unionized trucking. The industry was deregulated in 1980. And at that time truck, drivers were earning the equivalent of over $100,000 in today's dollars. And today, the typical truck driver will earn a little over $40,000 a year. I think it's an important part of the automation story. Why are they so afraid of automation? Because we've had four decades of rising inequality and wages. And if anybody is going to take it on the chin from automation in the trucking industry, the first in line is going to be the driver, without a doubt.

65.words: All right, that was the 10-minute documentary. We are still recording. Just wanted to make sure. All right. So something that I find really beautiful about these documentaries, the way that FRONTLINE chooses to capture the content, is that you can obviously tell that there are two very different perspectives. Those that are obviously naturally investing in this type of technology. You're creating this type of technology. And those who are at the other end of it in which they have this view of another ... "There's no way this could happen. And I'm currently in the position of my job potentially being taken over." So that's quickly to consider that we hear a wide range of opinions. And now we get to hear your opinions and just how you felt about different opinions and all of that jazz. So I'm going to begin with a few questions. We'll do one at a time and just go in a circle. It's like a graded conversation, but it's also not in the sense you're not graded. Thank you. I hate graded discussions. But the point is, once you hear a thought, just feel free to bounce off of that. It's a very free flowing conversation and I just like to hear as many voices as possible, just being mindful of balance and all of that jazz. Sound good? Great. All right. Your first question is, what is your central takeaway from this video? Now as you share, I want you guys to think about a story or an experience that might've been similar to what I shared of the documentary. It does not have to be about AI. But it may mirror the emotional or interpersonal issues that people were facing in the clip. So I can also start just to get the ball rolling. Is that okay with you guys or would someone like to jump in? I do see Kate looking for the microphone potentially? No. No. Okay, lovely. I can start then. I can't really say much about a personal experience. But generally speaking, I think that there is a concern about AI taking over a significant part of different industries. I, as all of you know, want to go into healthcare, which is a fairly recession proof industry for quite obvious reasons. But there are so many other fields and I know that a lot of you guys are going to the school of engineering or into entrepreneurship with your own individual interests. And having said that, I think that there's a lot, within the engineering field itself ... Like Karishma, I know that your dad often raves. Being like, "Yeah, it's great for AI." When you tell my dad too, he's like, "Oh, yeah, data science is great for AI." Because AI is essentially this brand new thing that's going to come in. And I hear this very common opinion that it's just going to take over everything and humans are going to become eternally useless, which is a terrifying thought. And so I think I was able to ... There was one moment where the guy was explaining to Mrs. Michigan, that lady whose husband was driving. And he was explaining, "Yeah, there were already trucks on the road and they were doing X, Y, Z." And her face was like, "Oh." And there was this ... Almost like a truth bomb or realization moment. And I think even though I'm not going into an industry with that concern per se, I could see a lot of current jobs being occupied in different industries. And so that fear I think is something that is well resonated within all kinds of different jobs. And in many ways, all of you know [inaudible]. He's a very far-sighted human. And so he's like, "Oh, god." In the future they might just have machines that can do diagnoses or there are obviously already things out there that will be like, "Give me your symptoms," and all of that jazz. And then will give you a big diagnosis or what your next steps should be. So I don't think it's far off in the future in which this opinion may come true per se. But in the case of ... I also watched this video, I think we watched it in school as well. When it comes to a car crash and a self-driving car, do you protect the driver inside your car, like the self-driving car, or a pedestrian or the other car in front of you? And I think the issue with self-driving cars and AI in general is there's so much debate about ethics when it comes to these algorithms. And I think the issue is not with the AI itself. Because AI, if you think about it, it's just a tool. It doesn't have a brain of its own necessarily, but it comes with the algorithms that people make for it. And I think that's the issue, is if we don't have a set on agreed rule of ethics, then you have these issues of when the computer starts going against humanity, it's because of the people who code it that way and don't follow the set on agreed rule of ethics.

71.words: Yeah, in general, there's a lot of pros and cons to this idea of replacing drivers with technology. A pro I think could be that ... Seeing the lifestyle of the truck driver that we saw, it's actually a very unhealthy lifestyle. They're often working more than 12-hour shifts. Especially the night drives, they're probably not getting enough sleep. And that's actually very dangerous on the road. So technology replacing that could be good. But also there's the issue of unskilled laborers now, if you think about the new market. And you have to think about solutions for that, whether that's finding a way to train them to be in part of ... For example, they could definitely be part of the quality assurance team like the QA team at those truck driving companies. Since they have that experience, they could be educated to identify those certain driving conventions that only truck drivers with experience would know. Whether that's communicating with other trucks or certain things on the road that they need to look out for. But it's very important to be able to balance both the pros of technology and how it advocates for safety, while also thinking about the labor and also the financial aspect of it.

79.words: One thing I would add, especially. So with that truck driver, I think there was an unfair comparison. He was the reporter, made about how truckers used to make $150,000, now he's making like $20,000. One, I think ... So when deregulation happened in the 80s, it wasn't driven by primarily by companies looking to make more profit. It was really just that the industry as a whole was unsustainable. People were just simply ... We couldn't afford to be paying people that kind of money. And over time, I think the industry of the small independent trucker, like the guy featured in the video, has really died off. And it is really a big struggle to make money in that. But there's a lot of truckers that still can make a lot of money operating as an owner operator for a larger firm. The average truck driver salary is double or triple the amount that this guy's making. And he seems like he's chill with it. But there's a price that he has to pay to be completely free and operating on his own, where you can make a lot more money by partnering with somebody else.

83.words: I can resonate with the experience that self-driving cars aren't ... They're fine. I don't use technology much and I don't know how to use technology much per se, and that's my own individual flaw. But as a lot of you know, I drive to dance a few times a week and my dance classes are an hour away. So we often end up taking the Tesla just because it's more convenient. And so I often go with my mom because she'll also want to sit in or do the class or whatever. And so if we're reviewing a piece or if I'm studying to manage that one hour commute there and back, with one hour being there, one hour being back, we often go on the self-driving mode thing. And obviously, it's like jerk the wheel every few seconds. And yeah, essentially, it's do something with the wheel for a hot second, so they just know that you're being present or whatnot. And the funniest story that I have is my mom does not refer to the Tesla as a car, but a toy. The reason being that she was driving once and I was trying to turn on the Bluetooth. So I swipe up and she wasn't using her Tesla car. And so what that means is her driver profile was on my dad's. My dad's obviously got much longer legs and he winds his seat all the way back so he can just throw his arms up and drive. So I was trying to click for the Bluetooth, and then I accidentally clicked on his name instead because that's like the driver profile it was on. And my mom's seat starts going back and she's still grabbing onto it. She's yelling at me, she's freaking out on the highway because she can't reach the pedal. And we're going from a hot 75 to 40 and there are cars zooming by. She thought there was an earthquake. And then she fixed it after realizing what happened. This is now funny. And then her first course of action was to yell at me, like, "What are you doing? Bluetooth." And I think that in itself is a pretty big flaw. What if my mom was a dwarf and she just wouldn't have been able to? This is not funny, but I'm being very serious in that that is not supposed to happen. Ideally, when you're driving, your drivers and speed settings shouldn't be in lock. And I think that there are small things like this that go unseen unless you really fit it with the system. And you all know that I really like to fit it with the system. But that's an anecdote that I had. And I know that our style of conversation as a friend group within YI happens to be a lot about, "Well, I feel or X, Y, Z." So I'd assume when we get more to a different place, there might be more job cutoffs as probably AI gets more centralized and stuff. But the point I was trying to get at is when you're a computer scientist, you do work a lot with coding.
